The radio frequency plasma was used to decorate the MCM-41 support or to treat the catalyst precursor. The structures and CO2 CH4 reforming performances of nickel-based catalysts prepared by different plasma treated modes were compared. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, FT-IR, H2-TPR, XPS, TEM, TG and contact angle. Comparing with the calcined catalyst supported on common MCM-41 (N-M-C), the plasma treated catalyst supported on plasma decorated MCM-41(N-MP-P) showed highest activity and best stability because of less Si-OH groups on support, smaller nickel particle size and more homogeneously dispersion as well as stronger interaction between nickel-MCM-41. The average CH4 and CO2 conversions were increased by 24.0% and 19.3%, respectively. After 30 h reaction, there was a little loss of the conversions, and the carbon deposition was decreased from 35.8% on N-M-C to 0.8% on N-MP-P; additionally, the Ni particle size was reduced from 20.9 to 8.5 nm, which proved that the coke resistance was apparently promoted. Comparing with the effect of plasma decorating the support, that of plasma treating the catalyst precursor played a more important role in the structure and catalytic performance of the Ni-based catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni-based catalyst Radio frequency plasma CO2-CH4 dry reforming Coke resistance Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the increasing emissions of carbon dioxide, reforming CH4 with CO2, which is called the dry reforming of methane (DRM) is considered as a feasible way to reduce greenhouse gasses and produce clean energy [1]. Supported Ni-based catalysts have been broadly studied for DRM reaction. They have showed comparable activity with noble metal-based catalysts and lower price [2]. However, it is easily inactivated due to the formation of coke deposition during the process of CO2 CH4 dry reforming [3]. For the economical industrial application, it is urgent to produce an efficient catalyst using nickel as active component possessed high activity, stability and coking resistance [4]. A conventional synthetic method of Ni catalysts for DRM reaction was impregnation method by dissolving chemical reagent contained Ni ions [5]. Then, the precursors were further calcined under air atmosphere with high temperature. As a result, sintering and aggregation of Ni active metals inevitably occurred. The high dispersion and smaller Ni crystalline diameter were difficulty obtained, thus directly influencing the catalytic performance of Ni-based catalysts and the formation rate of carbon deposition [6,7]. Therefore, developing an efficient catalyst precursor decomposition technique to reduce sintering and aggregation of Ni active metals is very important for DRM reaction. Compared with traditional calcination techniques, plasma technology rapidly gains interest of researchers as a promising method to prepare novel catalyst [8,9]. There are several varieties of nonthermal plasmas existing low gas temperature and high electron temperature which determine their unusual physical and chemical properties [10]. The surface of catalyst or precursor can be bombarded and sputtered by special species with high energy produced in the nonthermal plasma treatment. The plasma treatment process can be considered as the high-energy species bombard the catalyst surface. This process shows lower temperature and shorter treatment time than the calcination, and it generates the abundant defects at the catalyst surface [11,12]. Wang et al. [13] prepared the Ni/CeO2 catalyst treated by glow discharge plasma applying to glycerol steam reforming and found that the interaction between Ni and Ce was enhanced by plasma treatment. The formation of Ni-O-Ce special structure was beneficial to obtain high H2 selectivity and inhibite the formation of carbon deposition. Tang et al. [14] researched the MnOx catalysts with RF plasma modification for deNOX-SCR by propylene, and discovered that the formation rate of active Mn2O3 species was promoted by H2 RF plasma treatment. The highly dispersed Mn2O3 species were attributed to increasing the low temperature activity of C3H6-SCR catalysts. Liu et al. [15] prepared the Co-based catalysts with glow discharge plasma decoration. The dispersion of Co species and reaction activity was ultimately improved by the structure and surface properties of the RF modified support. Cheng et al. [16] prepared the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst using glow discharge plasma treatment. Their results found that the highly dispersed Ni cluster species were conducive to suppressing the Ni particles sizes increase, which decreased the formation rate of Cγ species. Seo et al. [17] prepared the Ni catalyst supported MgO support with RF plasma treatment. Their results showed that the nano-sized Ni particles and MgO nano rods catalysts had little carbon deposition. Therefore, radio frequency plasma was considered as an alternative process for catalysts modification due to high hydrogen selectivity, high stability, easily controlling Ni particles sizes, strong active mental-support interaction and resistance to carbon deposition. The structure and properties of support material are essential for promoting the performances of catalysts. MCM-41 is regarded as magnificent catalyst support with well-ordered mesoporous structure and higher specific surface area, which lead to more accessible and exposed active sites [18,19]. The performances of catalysts with pure MCM-41 support prepared by impregnation were not particularly excellent, unless the addition of promoters or the improvement of preparation methods were considered [20,21]. One of the reasons may be related to the preparation method and reaction process with high temperature and long time. Another reason could be considered as the large number of Si-OH groups on the surface of MCM-41, which are easy to combine with active metal hydroxide, resulting in uneven dispersion of Ni(OH)2 precursor on the surface of MCM-41 and agglomeration of Ni [22–24]. According to the literature reports [25–27], the results demonstrated that plasma modification and decoration could produce better properties for catalyst, which contributed to less crystallinity and smaller particle sizes of Ni, more reaction vacancy and active site, stronger bound interaction between Ni and support. However, many results so far were in a situation, which was related to the catalyst with plasma treatment or the reaction occurred on the plasma field. The investigation about support by plasma modification was very few. The comparison of the plasma treatment modification between the support and catalyst is necessary, which is helpful for further investigation and better exploring the relationship between RF plasma influence and the structure and surface properties of Ni-based catalysts. In our work, conventional MCM-41 support was modified by RF plasma; then calcination and RF plasma were introduced to treat the precursors prepared by impregnation with common MCM-41 support or plasma decorated MCM-41 support, respectively. The MCM-41 support and precursors by RF plasma treatment had been studied. The influence and consequence generated by RF plasma were analyzed to understand the enhanced resistance to carbon deposition. Their DRM reaction performances in CO2 CH4 dry reforming were explored and discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A purchasable MCM-41 was used as support and symbolled as “M”. Some of MCM-41 was modified by RF plasma treatment and marked as “MP”. RF plasma was excited with power 200 W under N2 atmosphere for treating 2 h and keeping pressure chamber at 20 kPa. Ni-based catalysts with 10 wt% nickel loading were loaded on the M or MP support by traditional incipient wetness impregnation method. After being dried at 80 °C for 6 h, the catalyst precursors were obtained. A part of the precursors was calcined at 550 °C for 4 h to obtain traditional thermal calcined Ni-based catalysts, marked as “N-M-C” and “N-MP-C”, respectively. Another part of the precursors was modified by RF plasma treatment with the same parameters compared with the treatment of MP support, marked as “N-M-P” and “N-MP-P”, respectively. 2.2 Characterizations The crystal structure analysis of catalysts was tested by X-ray diffraction (Siemens 6000 diffractometer, Shimadzu) with the parameters of 40 kV and 30 mA using Cu kα radiation. The scanning rate was 2°min−1 from 10° to 90° of XRD pattern. The functional groups of supports and catalysts were measured by Fourier transform infrared spectra using the UNICAM 4600 spectrometer. The tested spectral region from 400 to 4000 cm−1 used the 4 cm−1 resolution. The contact angle of the MP or M was measured using the DropMeterTM A-200 to analyze the surface hydrophilicity of supports. The binding energy and element content of catalysts were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+). All the binding energy was amended by C 1 s (284.8 eV). The reducibility of catalysts was investigated by H2-TPR using the INESORB-3010 (Finetec, China). Before the testing, the100 mg catalyst was fed into U-shaped quartz and preliminary treated for about 30 min on 300 °C with Ar. Then, the TPR measurement temperature went up to 800 °C using the 10 °C·min−1 warm rate under 10% H2/Ar. The carbon deposition of all spent catalysts was characterized by thermogravimetric analysis using the STA 2500 instrument. All catalysts test temperature was 30 °C–800 °C with the 10 °C min−1 heating rate using air atmosphere. The particle sizes and morphologies of the catalysts were characterized by transmission electron microscopy using Titan G260–300. 2.3 Catalytic stability The catalysts were 0.1 g put into a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor of 6 mm internal diameter, and then uprightly placed in reactor furnace with the quartz wool keeping warm. The stability and reactivity performance of catalysts was tested with the reactant gas GHSV of 36,000 mL g−1 h−1. The catalysts were reduced under H2 with the flaw rate of 16 ml min−1 at 700 °C using the 10 °C min−1 heating rate for 1.5 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the mixture gas of CH4 and CO2 with the molar ratio of 1 was to introduce the reactor at 750 °C with the 10 °C min−1 heating rate for 30 h reaction. The content of reactants and products was analyzed by gas chromatograph (SC-3000B-020) with SC108 packed column using TCD. Furthermore, the conversion of CH4 and CO2, the yield of CO, and the ratio of H2/CO were calculated using the following formulas. The Cin and Cout were the volume flow of the inlet and outlet, respectively. (1) C H 4 C o n v e r s i o n = C C H 4 , i n − C C H 4 , o u t C C H 4 , i n × 100 % (2) C O 2 C o n v e r s i o n = C C O 2 , i n − C C O 2 , o u t C C O 2 , i n × 100 % (3) C O Y i e l d = C c o , o u t C C H 4 , i n + C C O 2 , i n × 100 % (4) H 2 C O = C H 2 , o u t C c o , o u t 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and properties of supports and fresh catalysts XRD patterns of supports, fresh catalysts and reduced catalysts for N-M-C, N-MP-C, N-M-P, and N-MP-P were revealed in Fig. 1 . The SiO2 characteristic diffraction peak intensity of MP was stronger than that of M in Fig. 1(a), indicating that higher crystallinity was exhibited in the MP. In other words, the structure and surface properties of support were influenced by RF plasma treatment. As shown in Fig. 1(b), the diffraction peaks located at 2θ=37.5°, 43.4°, 63.1°, 75.6° and 79.4°, which belonged to the (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) crystal facets of NiO [28], were clearly observed on the fresh N-M-C and N-MP-C. The intensity of the diffraction peaks on N-M-P and N-MP-P catalysts treated by plasma significantly decreases, whether using M support or MP support. It identified that the RF plasma treatment on catalyst precursors could render the Ni species highly dispersed and obtain smaller particle size of Ni. However, comparing N-M-C with N-MP-C, the results showed that the RF plasma treatment on support did not obviously affect the properties of active metal on supported catalysts. Hence, it was thought that the influence of plasma treatment on the catalyst precursor was much greater than that on the support. Similar results were obtained on the reduced catalysts. In Fig. 1(c), the characteristic diffraction peaks assigned to (111), (200) and (220) crystal facets of Ni at 2θ=44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4° [29,30] were only observed on reduced N-M-C and N-MP-C catalysts. The diffraction peaks of Ni (111) for the N-M-C and N-MP-C catalysts were obviously observed. On the contrary, the Ni peak intensity of the catalysts treated by RF plasma were decreased. This decrease was attributed to the formation of smaller Ni particle sizes and higher dispersion of Ni species after RF plasma treating the catalyst precursors. The peak intensity of Ni for the N-MP-C catalyst was slightly reduced compared with the N-M-C catalyst, which was caused by the existence of small particle sizes of Ni. According to results reported by Hong et al. [31], CH4 decomposition mainly occurred on the Ni (111) plane, which leads to the retention and agglomeration of carbon atoms. Thus, the stronger diffraction peak of Ni (111) plane was beneficial to the retention of carbon atoms, which provided a favorable condition for the formation of carbon deposition. Besides, according to the Ni (111) (2θ=44.5°) plane, the different catalysts particle sizes were calculated using the Scherrer equation and ranked as follows: N-MP-P (5.4 nm) ˂ N-M-P (6.1 nm) ˂N-MP-C (15.4 nm) ˂ N-MP-C (18 nm). The particle sizes of catalysts using the MP support was slightly decreased compared with the catalysts using the M support. Therefore, the results proved that the precursors treated by RF plasma could efficiently obtain highly dispersed Ni and decrease the formation rate of Ni particle sizes. The characteristic chemical bonds of supports were identified by FT-IR spectroscopy. In Fig. 2 (a), the bands at 962 cm−1, 1090 cm−1, 1650 cm−1 and 3450 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibration of Si-OH groups, the stretch vibration of Si-O-Si groups, OH groups bending vibrations and OH groups stretching [15], respectively. Compared with the M, the intensity of these bands in plasma decorated sample was much lower, therefore leading to weaker hydrophilicity and reducing the adjacent hydroxyl groups number on the surface of MP support. The relationship between hydroxyl groups and hydrophilicity were consistent with the results of Al2O3 membranes hydrophilicity found by Gao et al. [32]. This conclusion was also consistent with the results of the contact angle. Fig. 2(c) showed the images of nickel nitrate solution droplets on the support surfaces of M and MP. The average contact angle of MP (35.1°) was higher than that of M (20.6°), indicating that the MP had a lower hydrophilicity. During the impregnation process, the lower hydrophilicity corresponded to the fewer hydroxyl groups. According to the reports [22,24], the dispersion of active metal and the interaction intensity between active metal and support were related to the content and properties of hydroxyl groups on support. During the process of impregnation, the higher dispersion of Ni(OH)2 was obtained on the MP surface because the hydroxyl groups of MP decreased by RF plasma treatment compared with using the M support. The characteristic chemical bonds of N-M-C, N-MP-C, N-M-P, and N-MP-P catalysts were identified by FT-IR spectroscopy. According to Fig. 2(b), the bands at 474 cm−1, 800 cm−1 and 1100 cm−1 belonged to the bending vibration of Si-O-Si groups, while the bands at 970 cm−1, 1640 cm−1and 3450 cm−1 caused by the vibration of Si-OH groups [12,24,33,34]. The peaks intensity of Si-O-Si groups (474 cm−1, 800 cm−1, 1100 cm−1) for the N-MP-C catalyst was enhanced compared with the N-M-C catalyst, which made the content of the negative charge increase. The increase in negative charge was beneficial to enhancing the interaction between Ni species and MP support and obtaining higher surface dispersion Ni consistent with the reports by Shu et al. [24]. However, for the RF plasma treatment catalysts N-MP-P and N-M-P, the bands peak intensity at 970 cm−1 decreased, indicating the precursors with RF plasma treatment possessed lower hydroxyl groups. This was consistent with the contact angle results. Furthermore, the band at 1380 cm−1 was caused by the bending vibration of the Si-O groups [35]. The peak intensity of Si-O groups (1380 cm−1) for the N-MP-P and N-M-P catalysts was enhanced declared that the content of Si-O groups was increased after RF plasma treatment, which enhanced the interaction between Ni and MP support. Besides, the strongest peak intensity of Si-OH groups (3450 cm−1) for the N-MP-P indicated that more Ni species entered the framework of the MP support, which lead to the special Si-OHNi species formation, being beneficial to enhancing the metal-support interaction, consistent with the reported results [33,34,36]. The distribution and valence of elements for fresh N-MP-P, N-M-P, and N-M-C catalysts were executed by XPS characterization (Fig. 3 ). In Fig. 3(a), the main peaks of Ni 2p3/2 spectrum of the N-M-C catalyst at 856.3 eV and 854.8 eV belonged to Ni(OH)2 and NiO species [37], respectively. The NiO binding energy of RF plasma treated catalysts moved to higher energy (855.9 eV for N-M-P catalyst and 856.1 eV for N-MP-P catalyst) compared with the N-M-C catalyst (854.8 eV). The N-MP-P catalyst had the highest NiO binding energy indicated that stronger interaction between NiO and MP support existed. The improvement of NiO binding energy could illustrate that the metal-support interaction was enhanced by RF plasma treatment. Besides, in Fig. 3(b), the main peaks of oxygen species were assigned to lattice oxygen (OL), surface adsorbed oxygen (OA), and hydroxyl oxygen (Ow) [38–40]. The content of surface adsorbed oxygen was increased by plasma treatment, and the N-MP-P catalyst possessed the highest one in Fig. 3(c). It was thought that RF plasma treatment could promote the decomposition of the catalyst precursor to enhance adsorbed oxygen content. The increased adsorbed oxygen contributed to the elimination of carbon deposition. However, the largest content of hydroxyl oxygen on the N-M-C catalyst indicated that the more Ni species distributed in the support surface due to the M support without RF plasma treatment leading to more hydroxyl groups, which extremely affected the content of Ni species entering the framework of support. The content of hydroxyl oxygen was decreased on the N-MP-P catalyst corresponding to more surface adsorbed oxygen. This reason could be attributed to two aspects. Firstly, the hydrophilicity of MP support was decreased by RF plasma treatment, leading to less hydroxyl groups existing on the MP support surface. Then, the decomposition of nickel nitrate was promoted by RF plasma treatment, resulting in more the formation of adsorbed oxygen. The detailed results of oxygen distribution were provided in Table S1. The fresh catalysts reducibility for N-M-C, N-MP-C, N-M-P, and N-MP-P were investigated by applying to H2-TPR characterization revealed in Fig. 4 . According to the N-M-C catalyst, the two reduction peaks in 373 °C and 389 °C were attributed to the reduction of nickel oxide on the surface of M support [41], and the reduction peak at 486 °C was caused by the reduction of nickel oxide in the support framework [42]. The high reduction temperature of the catalyst was ranked as follows: N-MP-P (686 °C) ˃ N-M-P (672 °C) ˃ N-MP-C (500 °C) ˃ N-M-C (486 °C). Interestingly, the temperature of reduction peak of the MP supported catalyst had a higher temperature compared with the M supported catalyst, whether the catalyst was further treated by plasma or calcination. Compared with the high reduction temperature of the N-M-P catalyst, the high reduction temperature of the N-MP-P catalyst moved to higher temperature, attributed to stronger metal-support interaction [43–45]. It was possibly attributed to the formation of Si-O-Ni species or Ni species embedded in MP support framework. The migration of active NiO species could be inhibited by strong interaction between Ni species and MP support, further preventing NiO agglomeration under the reforming reaction. Besides, compared with the high reduction temperature of the N-MP-C catalyst, a huge elevation was exhibited by the high reduction temperature of the N-M-P catalyst. It was obvious that the metal-support interaction was improved by RF plasma treatment catalyst precursor compared with traditional calcination. The H2 consumption of all catalysts was ranked as follows: N-MP-P (1865.3 mL/g) > N-M-P (1670.6 mL/g) >N-MP-C (866 mL/g) >N-M-C (533.4 mL/g). The H2 consumption of the N-MP-P catalyst was more enormous than that of other catalysts, which indicated more reducible and activated NiO species existed in the N-MP-P catalyst. 3.2 Catalytic behavior in methane reforming reaction The DRM performance of all catalysts was evaluated at 750 °C for 30 h reaction testing (shown in Fig. 5 ). Compared with the conversion and stability of the conventional calcination N-M-C catalyst, higher conversion and better stability of the RF-plasma-treated catalyst was exhibited. The initial CH4 conversion and CO2 conversion for the N-MP-P catalyst were 89.1% and 87.2%. The average CH4 conversion was increased from 57.0% (N-M-C) and 67.0% (N-MP-C) of calcined catalysts to 79.1% (N-M-P) and 81.1% (N-MP-P) of catalysts modified by RF plasma treatment, respectively. The average CO2 conversion was increased from 64.6% (N-M-C) and 73.5% (N-MP-C) of calcined catalysts to 82.2% (N-M-P) and 84.0% (N-MP-P) of catalysts modified by RF plasma treatment, respectively. Furthermore, using plasma treatment instead of calcination method could improve the catalyst stability. After 30 hs’ testing, the decrease rate of CH4 conversion was as follows: N-MP-P (12.7%) <N-M-P (13.1%) <N-MP-C (17.9%) <N-M-C (27.8%), and the order of the CO2 conversion loss was as follows: N-MP-P (4.6%) < N-M-P (7.1%) < N-MP-C (14.5%) <N-M-C (22.1%). Therefore, the N-MP-P catalyst had the best CH4 and CO2 conversion and stability. The catalyst with precursors treated by RF plasma could improve stability compared with that of traditional calcination treatment. According to Fig. 5(c), for the N-M-P and N-MP-P catalysts, a small difference in the CO yield was presented. This phenomenon was attributed to the precursors by RF plasma treatment and played a dominate role in catalysts modification and obtained better resistance to carbon deposition. The CO yield of the catalyst cannot be significantly improved with the repeated plasma treatment. However, for the N-M-P and N-MP-C catalysts CO yield, there was a great difference. The results showed that the catalysts stability was seriously affected by metal sintering on conventional high temperature calcination. As long as the catalyst was treated by the high temperature calcination, the catalytic activity of the catalyst was poor, regardless of plasma treatment. Therefore, even the N-MP-C catalyst was prepared by RF plasma treated MCM-41 support, the agglomeration and sintering of active metals could not be avoided. In addition, as shown in Fig. 5(d), the ratio of H2 to CO of the N-MP-P catalyst had always maintained 1.1, which indicated that the N-MP-P catalyst had a higher stability. The catalyst by using MP support with RF plasma treatment was compared with that of plasma untreated support. It was found that the catalyst supported by plasma decorated MCM-41 (MP) exhibited better activity and stability than the one supported by common MCM-41 (M). The average CH4 and CO2 conversions of the N-MP-C catalyst were increased by 9.9% and 8.9%, respectively, compared with that of the N-M-C catalyst. In addition, compared with that of the N-M-P catalyst, the CH4 and CO2 conversions of N-MP-P were also increased, about by 1.9% and 1.7%, respectively. There were several aspects to explain this result. First of all, higher crystallinity was exhibited in the MCM-41 support by RF plasma treatment, which could enhance the interaction between NiO and MP support. In the conventional untreated supports, the more hydroxyl groups on the MCM-41 surface would lead more Ni species on the MCM-41 surface, which extremely decreased the Ni content that entered the framework of MCM-41. However, highly dispersed Ni species were obtained on the RF treated MCM-41 surface. Finally, the negative charge of the MP support was increased by RF plasma treatment, which enhanced the interaction between Ni species and MP support. Therefore, compared with the N-M-C and N-M-P catalysts, the N-MP-C and N-MP-P catalysts showed higher conversion and stronger anti-coking performance. According to the results shown in Fig. 5, the different effects of the RF plasma treatment on the structure and surface properties of catalysts was investigated, which indicated that the improvement of plasma treatment on Ni-based catalyst precursor was more significant. RF plasma would generate more high-energy electrons to modify the catalyst [46]. These high-energy electrons bombarded the catalyst precursor to decompose the nickel nitrate, and promoted the nucleation of the nickel crystals, which resulted in producing more homogeneously dispersed small nickel particles. Moreover, when the bonds of the precursors were split, the modification of the support by the plasma was carried out at the same time. There were several aspects to explain this result. Firstly, the formation of smaller Ni particle sizes and higher dispersion of Ni species were obtained by RF plasma treatment precursors, decreasing the formation rate of larger Ni particle sizes. Secondly, the catalyst precursors treated by RF plasma could obtain lower hydroxyl groups and higher content of Si-O groups, which enhanced the metal-support interaction. The catalyst precursors with RF plasma modification indicated that more Ni species entered the framework of the MP support, being beneficial to enhancing the metal-support interaction. Then, RF plasma treatment could promote the decomposition of the catalyst precursor to enhance adsorbed oxygen content, facilitating the elimination of carbon deposition. Finally, the catalyst precursor treated by RF plasma would obtain difficult reduction NiO species, leading to strong interaction between NiO and MP support. Combined with the DRM reaction and characterization results, the resistance to carbon deposition and nickel-MCM-41 interaction of calcined catalyst was not as good as those of plasma treated catalyst precursor. In all tested samples, the N-MP-P catalyst exhibited the best activity and stability. According to the characterization and catalytic results, a possible mechanism was revealed in Fig. 6 . At first, the structure and surface properties of the MCM-41 were changed by RF plasma treatment, leading to the adjacent hydroxyl groups of support surface being removed, and then decreased the number of Si-OH groups on the support surface. During the impregnation progress, the fewer Si-OH groups play a positive role in enhancing Ni species dispersion and leading to more Ni species entering the MP framework. Then, the precursor was modified by RF plasma, obtaining smaller particle sizes and highly dispersed of Ni species and more surface adsorbed oxygen. Therefore, the N-MP-P catalyst exhibited the best performance of DRM reaction. Moreover, it was thought that compared with the RF plasma modifying support, the RF plasma treating catalyst precursor played a primary role in the DRM performance of catalyst. In brief, the catalyst prepared by combining the RF plasma decorated support with RF plasma activated precursor exhibited the optimal stability and resistance to carbon deposition. 3.3 Structure and properties of spent catalysts The state of chemical elements on the support surface of spent catalysts was characterized by XPS (Fig. 7 ). It exhibited that the spectra of Ni 2p3/2 of the spent N-M-C catalyst possessed two peaks around 852.7 eV and 855.5 eV shown in Fig. 7(A), which could be contributed to Ni0 species [37]. Compared with the spent N-M-C catalyst, the Ni 2p peaks of spent N-M-P and spent N-MP-P were shifted to higher binding energy (853.8 eV and 853.3 eV, respectively). The results demonstrated that using plasma technology was helpful for catalysts to maintain stronger Ni-MCM-41 interaction after the reaction, consistent with XPS findings of fresh catalysts (seen in Fig. 3). The O 1 s signals of spent catalysts were revealed in Fig. 7(b). The detailed data about oxygen species distribution were revealed in Table S3. The O 1 s spectra of the spent N-M-C catalyst appeared in three binding peaks positions caused by lattice oxygen (OL), absorbed oxygen (OA) and hydroxyl oxygen (OW), respectively [39]. According to Fig. 7(d), the content of surface adsorbed oxygen of the spent catalysts N-M-P and N-MP-P was increased by 6% and 7.9% compared with the spent N-M-C catalyst. The more content of surface adsorbed oxygen, the more beneficial for elimination of carbon deposition. According to Fig. 7(c), the C 1 s spectra of the spent N-M-C catalyst exhibited four peaks, at 283.5 eV attributed to CC, 284.8 eV related to C = C, 286.0 eV and 288.5 eV belonged to COH and C = O, respectively [47–49]. For all spent catalysts, the peak corresponding to CC manifested the presence of graphitic carbon which could lead to the deactivation of catalyst. Those results showed that the stronger Ni-MP interaction of the catalyst N-MP-P prevented the Ni particle sizes continuous growing. According to reports [22,25,28], the main reason for particle sizes increasing was carbon deposition persistent forming and staying on the Ni particle surface. Then, more surface adsorbed oxygen species could facilitate the elimination of inactive carbon deposition. Therefore, the CC binding energy of the spent N-M-C (283.5 eV) catalyst was higher than that of the spent N-M-P (283.4 eV) and N-MP-P (283.2 eV) catalysts. The higher CC binding energy corresponded to a higher degree of graphitic carbon indicated that more the existence of non-activated carbon species, leading to serious carbon deposition and catalyst deactivation, which was consistent with the results [50,51]. Besides, the spent N-MP-P catalyst had broader CC peak compared with the spent N-M-P catalyst, which proved the presence of filamentous carbon and graphitic carbon, consistent with the results [52]. The stronger performance for suppressing carbon deposition formation of the N-MP-P catalyst enhanced by RF plasma treatment was interrelated with the presence of filamentous carbon. During the process of reaction, the formation of graphitic carbon was suppressed by more adsorbed oxygen and simultaneously facilitating the elimination of carbon deposition. In conclusion, the N-MP-P catalyst had stronger metal-support interaction and more adsorbed oxygen, which provided a stronger resistance to carbon deposition. The spent catalysts carbon deposition for N-M-C, N-MP-C, N-M-P, and N-MP-P were investigated by applying to TG characterization shown in Fig. 8 . On the DTG curves(Fig. 8(b)), the temperature peak at 250 °C ∼ 400 °C was considered as the removal of amorphous carbon [53]. The temperature peak at 500 °C–700 °C was assigned to the removal of graphitic carbon [54,55]. The exothermic and endothermic peaks of the DTG curve corresponded to weight loss on the TG curve. The order of carbon deposition amount produced on different used catalysts was as follows: N-M-C (35.8%) > N-MP-C (31.9%) > N-M-P (1.4%) > N-MP-P (0.8%). Compared with the spent N-M-C catalyst, the carbon deposition content of spent N-MP-P catalyst was reduced by 35.0%. It was found that the carbon deposition content of plasma treated spent catalysts (N-M-P and N-MP-P) was much lower than that on the spent calcined catalysts (N-M-C and N-MP-C). This indicated that the catalysts with their precursors activated by RF plasma displayed a markedly improved coke resistance performance, which might be because of smaller particle sizes and higher dispersion of Ni species, as well as stronger Ni-MCM-41 interaction and more surface oxygen species. In addition, the carbon deposition content of spent catalysts supported by plasma decorated MCM-41 (N-MP-P or N-MP-C) was a little lower than that on the corresponding spent catalysts supported by common MCM-41 (N-M-C or N-M-P). According to Liu et al. [43] reported results, the content and formation rate of carbon deposition was influenced by Ni particle sizes. While, higher dispersion and stronger Ni-MP interaction could reduce the migration and agglomeration of Ni particle under high temperature reaction [19], which was conducive to control the Ni particle size. According to the results of contact angle and FT-IR, the hydroxy groups on the MP support were decreased, which contributed to improve the Ni dispersion. Besides, according to the TPR results, the temperatures of reduction peaks of the MP supported catalysts were higher than those of the M supported catalysts. It was indicated that using plasma decorated MCM-41 as support could further enhance the interaction between Ni and MP support. The reported carbon deposition on different DRM catalysts were gathered in Fig. 8(c) [16,19,23,29,54,56–62], the carbon deposition on the N-MP-P catalyst was less. Therefore, it could be considered that the N-MP-P catalyst had excellent stability and anti-coking performance. The spent catalysts morphology and surface carbon species for N-M-C, N-M-P, and N-MP-P were investigated by applying to TEM characterization shown in Fig. 9 . According to Fig. 9(a), the larger Ni particle sizes (45 nm) was obviously observed on the spent N-M-C catalyst caused by serious agglomeration of Ni particles and formation of graphitic carbon. It was observed that Ni particles surrounded by graphitic carbon (marked with 1), a mass of encapsulating carbon (marked with 2), and a small number of filamentous carbon (marked with 3). The shadow surrounding Ni particles was considered as more amount of encapsulating carbon also formed on the N-M-C catalyst surface. Meanwhile, less translucent shadow away from Ni particle was also regarded as the existence of filamentous carbon. However, according to Fig. 9(b), the Ni particle sizes became smaller, surrounded by less graphitic carbon. Fewer filamentous carbons and encapsulating carbons were observed on the Ni particles around the spent N-M-P catalyst. For Fig. 9(c), more filamentous carbon was observed on the spent N-MP-P catalyst, and existing less encapsulating carbon and graphitic carbon, which was consistent with the different carbon species of XPS results. Besides, the size distributions of Ni nanoparticle on the spent catalysts were present in Fig. 9(d–f). The average Ni particle sizes of the spent N-M-C, N-M-P, and N-MP-P catalysts were 20.9 nm, 9.5 nm, and 8.5 nm, respectively. The larger Ni particle sizes (45 nm) was obviously observed on the spent N-M-C catalyst, which indicated serious agglomeration occurred during the reaction. At the same time, the RF plasma treatment catalysts had smaller Ni particle sizes than that of thermal calcination catalysts. The reason for this result was attributed to the growth rate of Ni crystal decreased by RF plasma treatment, thus obtaining smaller Ni particle sizes and stronger resistance to carbon deposition. However, well dispersed Ni species in the N-M-P and N-MP-P catalysts demonstrated that the aggregation of active components would be inhibited by RF plasma treatment. It was indicated that the plasma treated catalysts had much smaller Ni particle size after 30 h high temperature DRM reaction, compared with the calcined catalyst. After a long time reaction, the Ni particle sizes of the spent N-M-P, and N-MP-P catalysts were still small. Meanwhile, for the plasma decorated MCM-41 supported catalyst (Fig. 9(c) and (f)), the Ni particles were better crystallized and smaller than the regular MCM-41 supported one (Fig. 9(b) and (e)), consistent with XRD findings (Fig. 1(c)). Moreover, there was no obvious carbon deposition the spent N-M-P, and N-MP-P catalysts, which indicated that the plasma treated catalysts had higher stability and better resistance to carbon formation, consistent with XPS and TG findings after reaction (Figs. 7(c) and 8). The reported Ni particle sizes, reaction conversion, and weight loss of the carbon deposition were listed in Table 1 . There was less carbon deposition on the N-MP-P catalyst compared with other catalysts. For the N-MP-P catalyst, plasma decorated support possessed weaker hydrophilicity and less hydroxyl groups, which could inhibit the interaction between Si-OH and Ni(OH)2 during the impregnation process. It was beneficial to enhance the dispersion of Ni species. Using RF plasma technology instead of traditional thermal calcination to treat catalyst precursor obtained by impregnation could obtain much smaller nickel particles and more homogeneously Ni dispersion because of the effectively decomposition of nickel nitrate and fast nucleation with low temperature and short time in plasma field. Additionally, the smaller nickel particles produced in the plasma field tended to interact strongly with support, leading to the stabilization of active components from agglomerating and sintering, and reducing coke deposition during DRM reaction. Combining with the results of DRM reaction and characterization, the effect of plasma treating catalyst precursor on structure and catalytic performance of Ni-based catalyst was more remarkable than that of plasma decorating support. 4 Conclusions For the improvement of CO2-CH4 reforming performance of Ni-based catalyst, the RF plasma was used to modified the MCM-41 support or treat the catalyst precursor. Characterization and reaction results illustrated that the catalysts by plasma treated precursor showed higher activity and better stability in DRM reaction than that prepared by thermal calcined precursor. The XRD of fresh catalysts and TEM of spent catalysts exhibited that the RF plasma treatment resulted in much smaller nickel particle size and more homogeneously dispersion, compared with thermal calcination which led to forming agglomerated and larger Ni particles. The average particle size of the spent N-MP-P catalyst was 8.5 nm, and that of spent N-M-C was 20.9 nm. A stronger Ni-MP interaction on plasma treated catalysts proved by TPR and XPS results was beneficial for preventing the migration and agglomeration of active nickel metal during the high temperature and reaction process. Simultaneously, the MCM-41support surface properties were altered by RF plasma treatment. According to the IR and contact angle results, plasma decorated support possessed weaker hydrophilicity and less hydroxyl groups, which could benefit in improving the dispersion of Ni species. However, comparing with the effect of plasma decorating support, that of plasma treating catalyst precursor played a chief part in the structure and catalytic performance of the Ni-based catalyst in DRM reaction. The plasma treated catalyst supported on plasma decorated MCM-41 (N-MP-P) showed highest activity and best stability. Compared with the calcined catalyst supported on common MCM-41 (N-M-C), the average CH4 and CO2 conversions of N-MP-P were increased by 24.0% and 19.3%, respectively. Meanwhile, after 30 h reforming reaction, the results of TG for spent catalysts indicated that the carbon deposition was decreased from 35.8% on N-M-C to 0.8% on N-MP-P. The coke resistance was greatly enhanced. coredata.dc:description: The radio frequency plasma was used to decorate the MCM-41 support or to treat the catalyst precursor. The structures and CO2 CH4 reforming performances of nickel-based catalysts prepared by different plasma treated modes were compared. The catalysts were characterized by XRD, FT-IR, H2-TPR, XPS, TEM, TG and contact angle. Comparing with the calcined catalyst supported on common MCM-41 (N-M-C), the plasma treated catalyst supported on plasma decorated MCM-41(N-MP-P) showed highest activity and best stability because of less Si-OH groups on support, smaller nickel particle size and more homogeneously dispersion as well as stronger interaction between nickel-MCM-41. The average CH4 and CO2 conversions were increased by 24.0% and 19.3%, respectively. After 30 h reaction, there was a little loss of the conversions, and the carbon deposition was decreased from 35.8% on N-M-C to 0.8% on N-MP-P; additionally, the Ni particle size was reduced from 20.9 to 8.5 nm, which proved that the coke resistance was apparently promoted. Comparing with the effect of plasma decorating the support, that of plasma treating the catalyst precursor played a more important role in the structure and catalytic performance of the Ni-based catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: High activity and strong coke resistance of nickel CO2-CH4 reforming catalyst promoted by different plasma treated modes
